content: The Act is titled the "National Commission on Employment and Economic Security Act". It includes findings related to employment and economic security. During the recession, over 8.7 million jobs were lost, impacting individuals across the economic spectrum. Job loss often leads to loss of health insurance and housing, increasing the risk of severe depressive symptoms for those facing home foreclosure. During the recession, job loss led to over 8.7 million jobs lost, impacting individuals across the economic spectrum. This loss of a job and subsequent loss of income, insurance, and benefits have been proven to increase stress and trigger mental health disorders like depression and anxiety. Home foreclosure puts individuals at risk for severe depressive symptoms, with more than 37 percent meeting criteria for major depression. Calls to the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline increased by over 72 percent from 2007 to 2010, coinciding with an unemployment rate between 8.9 and 10 percent from April 2009 to October 2011. During the recession from 2009 to October 2011, the number of unemployed persons peaked at 10.0 percent in October 2009, reaching nearly 15.4 million. The number of long-term unemployed workers increased by 426 percent since the beginning of the recession in 2007, with 6.2 million jobless for 27 weeks or more in September 2011. Money, work, and the economy were the most cited sources of stress for Americans during the recession, with 76 percent, 70 percent, and 65 percent respectively. Since March 2010, 7.5 million private-sector jobs have been created in 42 straight months of job growth. Job stability rose as a source of stress, with 49 percent of adults reporting it in 2010 compared to 44 percent in 2009. Time flexible work policies are linked to less stress, fewer absences, and increased employer loyalty. Satisfaction with employer support in balancing work and non-work demands decreased to 36 percent from 42 percent in 2009. Since March 2010, 7.5 million private-sector jobs have been created in 42 consecutive months of job growth, reducing the unemployment rate from 9.9 percent to 7.2 percent. The Congressional Budget Office predicts that the unemployment rate will not drop below 6 percent until the end of 2016 and will stay above 5 percent until 2023. Establishment of the "National Commission on Employment and Economic Security" with duties outlined. The National Commission on Employment and Economic Security will examine economic and psychological insecurity in the US workforce due to employment displacement. It will gather data on the relationship between psychological stress, mental health disorders, and workplace violence. Additionally, it will analyze the impact of workplace responsibilities and stress on current workers and the effects of decreasing well-paid jobs. The National Commission on Employment and Economic Security will analyze the impact of decreasing well-paid jobs on the US workforce and their families. It will also recommend potential solutions to alleviate economic and psychological insecurity among workers. The National Commission on Employment and Economic Security will analyze the impact of decreasing well-paid jobs on the US workforce and their families, and recommend solutions to alleviate economic and psychological insecurity among workers. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP OF COMMISSION. The Commission consists of 17 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and minority leader of the House. Members have expertise in research methods or statistics and represent labor organizations, business interests, mental health interests, and relevant Federal agencies. The Commission consists of 17 members appointed by various leaders. Members must be experts in labor, employment, economics, and psychology. Appointments must be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment, and members serve for life without pay. Travel expenses are covered for each member. The Commission consists of 17 members appointed by various leaders who must be experts in labor, employment, economics, and psychology. Members serve for life without pay and receive travel expenses. Eight members constitute a quorum, the Chairperson is elected by the members within 30 days, and meetings are called by the Chairperson. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint staff and determine their pay. The staff must adhere to certain civil service laws and may request personnel from federal agencies to assist in their duties. The Commission also has specific powers outlined in Section 7. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, administer oaths, and receive evidence. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can obtain necessary information from federal departments, use the United States mail, and exercise powers outlined in Section 7. The Commission, as an agency of the United States, has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to its responsibilities under the Act. The Administrator of General Services can provide administrative support services to the Commission upon request. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence. If a person refuses to obey a subpoena, the Commission can seek a court order for compliance. Subpoenas must be served in accordance with the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. The Commission also has the ability to contract with others. The Commission has the authority to contract with government and private agencies for supplies or services, without following certain statutes. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within a year of all members being appointed. The Commission will terminate 60 days after submitting the report, during which it can conclude activities and provide testimony to Congress. Authorization of appropriations is also included. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $2,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 2012 for plans under this Act. Amounts remain available until expended.
